PAN AMERICA
Pan American
Fed EClippor departs Naw
scheduled jet passenger flight to S
" York for first
Paris, Odober 26, 19.58
Ring Pies

Visorio First Flighs of Dan Amorican Slippers
Dan Atmorican Jet Lipper departs Nice Work
for first scheduled jed passenger flight to Paris,
Odebor 26, 19.58
American aviation enters the jet era as Pan Am Jet Clipper America (N711PA), commanded by Captain
Samuel H. Miller, takes off from rain-soaked New York International Airport bound for Paris with 111 passengers
This was the first scheduled commercial jet flight by a United States airline.
The Boeing B707 jet, flying at 575 miles an hour, reduced the crossing time - once 23 hours - to seven
hours. With this flight Pan Am's Boeing B707s and Douglas DC-8s began leading the way in bringing the ad-
vantages of jet travel to more than 80 lands around the world.
Like no other aircraft that preceded it, the Jet Clippers shrunk the globe, putting any point on the earth's sur
face within 24 hours of any other point and boosting air traffic volume to new highs.
About the Artist
In 1926, John T. McCoy became a working student for the Curtiss Flying Ser-
vice, Curtiss Field, Long Island, New York.
When Charles A. Lindbergh arrived at Curtiss Field, his SPIRIT OF ST. LOUIS
was housed in one of the Curtiss hangars. It was at this time that McCoy met
Lindbergh, who was most cordial and friendly to those who worked on the flight
line. In those days muscle power was the method used for starting engines, ac
complished by swinging the propeller by hand. McCoy often pulled a prop through
for Lindbergh.
Years later, when McCoy was commissioned to do paintings depicting the
history of Pan American World Airways, Inc. - entitled HISTORIC FIRST FLIGHTS
OF PAN AMERICAN CLIPPERS - he consulted with Lindbergh on the selection of
aircraft and locations for the series.
This is one picture in a series of thirteen. If you would like to purchase 8½"x 11*
or 16 × 20° limited edition prints, send your letter of inquiry to: Public Relations
Department - Pan American World Airways, Inc., Pan Am Building, New York, New
York 10166. Please include code number 304 in your letter.

properties.sfomuseum:description: Menu issued by Pan American World Airways; color reproduction of a watercolor of Boeing 707 with caption, "Pan American Jet Clipper departs New York for first scheduled jet passenger flight to Paris, October 26, 1958"; includes information about historic flight and artist; entree selection includes tenderloin of beef roasted on board and carved to order, and roasted duckling in Calvados cream sauce garnished with baked apple and bing cherries; menu number 221 9-18-84.
